handDesc.p: Tidy monumental script, with characters profoundly engraved. However, some vocalic marks (hulu, taling tarung for vocalization o) are not as profoundly engraved as others and are only faintly visible. Note the two different shapes of pasangan y. It seems that the boundary between words is emphasized by a slightly larger space.

div.p:
Om̐ sri sarasoti kr̥ta, vukir hadidamaluṁ Uri
piṁ buhana hañakra murusa patirtan paL̥maran· hapan yaṁ
vidi hanidenihamideni yaṁ raditya yaṁ vulan· hanəL̥ I hala-hayu
ni devamanusa yaṁ hanut yaṁ hagave bajaran tapak taṁtu kabaḥhakambaha
deni devamanusa muvaḥ saṁ tumon saṁṅ amanah aR̥ṅə luputa
riṁ Ila-Ila paḍa kadəlana tutur jati

yen ana ṅabaḥṅambaḥ ta
n pabəkəla patik vənaṁ tan pabaktaha histri pituṁ hajama tan vava
dona vastu, sri syatśrī syāt i sakavarsa .

app.note: The anunāsika is noted with a sign identical to the layar used elsewhere in this inscription. See Cohen Stuart (1872: 279)

div.p: Om. Made by Śrī Sarasvatī. The mountain Ādidamaluṅ, the life of the Earth, was churning. The bathing place of Paləmaran would overflow, for God Vidhi i.e. Brahmā? gave instructions amidhyani to the Sun and the Moon to illuminate the bad and good of divine men, those who seek, those who make a line of succession. The established sacred site will be entered by divine men. And those paḍa who watch, who are intent, who listen, will be free from defilement, will be invested with memory of former lives. Should anyone enter, he shall not come provided with live-stock, shall not bring wives pituṅ to have intercourse with, shall really vastu not be obsessed with sex. May there be Fortune! In the Śaka year 1371.
